org.openadaptor.auxil.convertor.fixedwidth
Class AbstractFixedWidthStringConvertor

java.lang.Object
  org.openadaptor.core.Component
      org.openadaptor.auxil.convertor.AbstractConvertor
          org.openadaptor.auxil.convertor.fixedwidth.AbstractFixedWidthStringConvertor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Administrable, IComponent, IDataProcessor
Direct Known Subclasses:
FixedWidthStringToOrderedMapConvertor, OrderedMapToFixedWidthStringConvertor
public abstract class AbstractFixedWidthStringConvertor
extends AbstractConvertor

Defines the common elements of a fixed width converter.

There are multiple attributes that define a field in the fixed width world (ie. name, width, to be trimmed, etc.) and we have a specific class to represent this. The field details are defined in the properties file and Swing will instantiate them for us.

These field details are common to both conversion to and from fixed width string so we have an abstract implementation of the IDataProcessor which maintains code that manipulates them.

Author:
Russ Fennell
See Also:
IDataProcessor, FixedWidthFieldDetail, AbstractFixedWidthStringConvertor, FixedWidthStringToOrderedMapConvertor

setFieldWidths

public void setFieldWidths(java.lang.Integer[] widths)
Sets the field widths only. Actually, just creates field details with default values for name, trim, etc.

There are two occasions when this method is called:

  1. as part of the Spring properties bootstrap process - we need to create a new fieldDetail for each width
  2. when being updated by the properties editor - we need to update the appropriate fieldDetail as well

Parameters:
widths - list of the field widths
Throws:
ValidationException - if the field details have already been set or if you define both field details and widths

getFieldNames

public java.util.ArrayList getFieldNames()
Returns:
a list of the field names defined

hasFieldNames

public boolean hasFieldNames()
Returns:
true if any of the field details have their names set

getTotalFieldWidth

public int getTotalFieldWidth()
Returns:
the size of the record which is the sum of the individual field widths

getMinimumRecordSize

public int getMinimumRecordSize()
Returns the minimum size that a record must be before it can be chopped or -1 if there are no field details defined.

The minimum size is calculated as the total width of all fields bar the last one if it's to be trimmed.

isValidFieldName

public boolean isValidFieldName(java.lang.String name)
Returns:
false if the field name supplied is null or an empty string
Throws:
ValidationException - if there are multiple fields defined with the same name
